channel.title: PSP Kernel
channel.description:
For my Computer Science final, we have to develop a kernel for an embedded system. We're supposed to be working in teams of five or six, but the team that I was assigned to decided to go out to the casino half a mile down the road, get unruly, and now they're on academic probation for a while. So instead of putting me in another team, my teacher said that I still need to do it, even if I'm by myself.
So anyway, I decided to be an over achiever like I always am, and I asked my teacher if I could develop a kernel for the PSP(bad decision). He said that it was cool, but wanted to know if I was up to the task, and I said of course(another bad decision). So I guess what I want to know is if anyone has any resources I might be able to use for developing a kernel. I've been learning C++ in school, and that's what the instructor wants us to make the kernel in.

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

Hackaday – 12 Oct 10

ARM prototyping on-the-cheap with STM32 Discovery

STMicroelectronics has another inexpensive development board out; the STM32 Discovery is an ARM Cortex-M3 prototyping platform. Coming in under $10 puts it right along the lines of their 8-bit offe…

shit IDEs but you can use gcc

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:15, topic:383835”]It actually wouldn’t be remotely hard to boot a C++ kernel on it, assuming you were willing to accept a limited subset of C++ features (ie, no introspection, which kills various other things)

edit: though like others, i’d pick a simpler device. does it even have to be a commercially available device?[/quote]

Ya, the instructor said it has to be commercially available, and we have to be able to flash our kernel onto the device, and be able to return it to it’s original state.

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It actually wouldn’t be remotely hard to boot a C++ kernel on it, assuming you were willing to accept a limited subset of C++ features (ie, no introspection, which kills various other things)

edit: though like others, i’d pick a simpler device. does it even have to be a commercially available device?

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

GBA would be my choice

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

zyle1992:

Actually you can “just use sony’s bootloader and tell it to load your own kernel”. You just put the battery into service mode, tell the device to boot the ipl(basically boot file) off the memory stick, and you’re good(from what I’ve researched). I’m just having a problem creating a mips toolchain =\

That is still sony’s kernel though…custom firmware != a new kernel someone wrote from scratch

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:11, topic:383835”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=479598.msg3512608#msg3512608 date=1298697784]
There is nothing wrong with writing a kernel in C++, it can and has been done.
[/quote]
Perhaps the kernel itself could be written in C++ but it’s not like you can just use sony’s bootloader and tell it to load your own kernel, you would have to start from scratch and presumably write a fair bit of assembly just to get the thing running.[/quote]

Actually you can “just use sony’s bootloader and tell it to load your own kernel”. You just put the battery into service mode, tell the device to boot the ipl(basically boot file) off the memory stick, and you’re good(from what I’ve researched). I’m just having a problem creating a mips toolchain =\

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Moparisthebest:

There is nothing wrong with writing a kernel in C++, it can and has been done.

Perhaps the kernel itself could be written in C++ but it’s not like you can just use sony’s bootloader and tell it to load your own kernel, you would have to start from scratch and presumably write a fair bit of assembly just to get the thing running.

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

To write a kernel you obviously need to know a lot about the language you’re using, not “learning in high school”, which is why I’m wondering why you even wanted to write a kernel for a device like that, all on your own.

Learn about ARM or something, none of your other classmates will make anything decent anyway

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Just to emphasis MITB point, make sure you pick a well documented device, it will make your work much easier and be able to score higher as you will understand it more.

Read full topic

item.title: PSP Kernel
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:383835”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=479598.msg3512009#msg3512009 date=1298653469]
good luck writing a kernel using c++

the fact the the psp is a proprietary closed device makes this even more of fucking retarded idea.
[/quote]

There is nothing wrong with writing a kernel in C++, it can and has been done.

You should have picked an open, well documented device though, why not just tell your teacher you changed your mind?[/quote]

Yeah, the next time I’m in that class is tomorrow morning. I’ll talk to him then.

Read full topic
